note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA
Patient: Henry Walker, 63-year-old male with a spiculated right upper lobe mass and borderline mediastinal nodes.
Indication: Mediastinal staging prior to lobectomy.
Setting: Bronchoscopy suite, Harbor Pulmonary Institute. Deep sedation with propofol infusion, native airway with bite block and supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
Findings: Normal vocal cords. Central airways patent without visible endobronchial tumor. Mild extrinsic compression at right mainstem.
EBUS: Olympus BF-UC180F scope used. Systematic survey of mediastinum. Lymph nodes identified and sampled at 2R, 4R, and 7 using 21G Vizishot needle. Three passes obtained per station. ROSE adequate at all stations with lymphocytes only; no definite malignant cells.
No elastography or intranodal forceps biopsies performed.
Complications: None. EBL <5 mL. No hypoxia or arrhythmia.
Disposition: Observed in recovery for 90 minutes and discharged home with standard postbronchoscopy instructions.
primary_indication: Mediastinal staging for right upper lobe lung mass
radiographic_findings: 3.0 cm spiculated RUL mass with borderline 2R, 4R nodes on CT
ebus_rose_result: Adequate lymphocytes at all stations; no definite malignant cells on ROSE
ebus_stations_detail: Three passes per station, samples sent for cytology and cell block.
bronch_indication: EBUS-TBNA for mediastinal staging
bronch_specimen_tests: Cytology and cell block with immunohistochemistry if malignant cells found
final_diagnosis_prelim: No mediastinal metastasis identified on ROSE; final cytology pending
disposition: Discharged home from bronchoscopy recovery area
follow_up_plan: Thoracic surgery clinic within 1 week to review final results and plan resection

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Linear EBUS-TBNA under general anesthesia in the operating room
Patient: Allison Parker, 57-year-old female with biopsy-proven right lower lobe adenocarcinoma and equivocal PET uptake in subcarinal node.
Indication: Mediastinal staging (station 7) prior to definitive therapy.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 7.5 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
EBUS Details: Fujifilm EB-530US scope advanced through ETT. Stations 4R, 7, and 10R evaluated. A 22G needle was used; four passes obtained from station 7, three from 4R, two from 10R. ROSE demonstrated malignant cells at station 7 consistent with adenocarcinoma; other stations reactive.
No elastography available; no intranodal forceps performed.
Complications: None. EBL ~5 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to PACU in stable condition; admitted to oncology floor.
primary_indication: Mediastinal staging for right lower lobe adenocarcinoma
radiographic_findings: Right lower lobe mass with borderline subcarinal node, mild PET uptake at station 7
ebus_rose_result: Station 7 positive for malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma; 4R and 10R reactive
ebus_stations_detail: Multiple passes at each station with adequate lymphoid tissue on ROSE.
bronch_indication: EBUS-TBNA for mediastinal staging
bronch_specimen_tests: Cytology, cell block, immunohistochemistry
final_diagnosis_prelim: N2 disease at station 7; final cytology pending
disposition: Admitted to oncology ward after PACU
follow_up_plan: Tumor board review; likely definitively treated with chemoradiation rather than surgery

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Linear EBUS with elastography and intranodal forceps biopsy
Patient: Eric Johnson, 69-year-old male with suspected sarcoidosis and enlarged mediastinal/hilar nodes.
Indication: Tissue diagnosis of mediastinal adenopathy.
Sedation: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol infusion.
EBUS findings: Enlarged nodes at 4R, 7, and 11L. Elastography showed predominantly blue heterogenous pattern at 4R and 7 and green pattern at 11L. A 22G needle was used for TBNA at all three stations with three passes each. Intranodal forceps biopsies were performed at station 7 through prior needle tract.
ROSE: Granulomatous-appearing inflammation at station 7.
Complications: Self-limited bleeding after forceps biopsy.<5 mL EBL.
Disposition: Discharged home same day.
primary_indication: Diagnosis of mediastinal lymphadenopathy in suspected sarcoidosis
radiographic_findings: Bilateral hilar and mediastinal adenopathy with perilymphatic nodules
ebus_rose_result: Granulomatous inflammation at station 7; benign lymphocytes at 4R and 11L
ebus_elastography_pattern: Heterogeneous blue at 4R/7, homogeneous green at 11L
ebus_stations_detail: Intranodal forceps biopsies from station 7 following TBNA; samples sent for histology and special stains.
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopy with EBUS for sarcoidosis workup
bronch_specimen_tests: EBUS-TBNA and intranodal forceps biopsies for histology, AFB, fungal stains
final_diagnosis_prelim: Granulomatous lymphadenitis consistent with sarcoidosis; special stains pending
follow_up_plan: Clinic follow-up in 2 weeks to review final pathology and adjust immunosuppression

note_text:
Bronchoscopy Procedure Note
Procedure: Radial EBUS-guided biopsy of right middle lobe nodule (no navigation)
Patient: Janice Moore, 71-year-old female with 15 mm RML nodule not amenable to CT-guided biopsy.
Sedation: Moderate sedation (midazolam and fentanyl), native airway.
Procedure summary:
- Diagnostic bronchoscopy performed; central airways normal.
- Radial EBUS catheter advanced through guide sheath into RML lateral segment based on fluoroscopy and CT roadmap.
- Concentric solid lesion pattern obtained.
- Four transbronchial forceps biopsies and two brushings performed through guide sheath.
ROSE: Suspicious for malignancy.
Complications: Minimal bleeding. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home after observation.
primary_indication: Biopsy of peripheral right middle lobe pulmonary nodule
radiographic_findings: 15 mm solid RML lateral segment nodule abutting bronchus; no adenopathy
lesion_location: Right middle lobe lateral segment peripheral nodule
ebus_rose_result: Atypical cells suspicious for non-small cell carcinoma
nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view within lesion
nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopic confirmation of guide sheath position
nav_sampling_tools: Transbronchial forceps and cytology brush via guide sheath
bronch_indication: Radial EBUS-guided biopsy of RML nodule
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, immunohistochemistry, molecular panel if NSCLC confirmed
final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspicious for NSCLC; final pathology pending
follow_up_plan: Lung nodule clinic appointment in 7–10 days to review results

note_text:
Robotic Bronchoscopy / EBUS Note
Procedures:
1. Ion robotic-assisted bronchoscopy
2. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT
3. Transbronchial cryobiopsy and forceps biopsy of LUL nodule
Patient: Olivia Carter, 59-year-old female with 20 mm left upper lobe nodule and normal mediastinal imaging.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT; pressure control ventilation.
Details: Robotic catheter navigated to apicoposterior segment of LUL using CT-to-body registration (error 2.1 mm). Concentric radial EBUS view obtained. Cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion. Three cryobiopsies (1.1 mm cryoprobe) and three standard forceps biopsies performed.
ROSE from cryobiopsy: Malignant epithelial cells, favor adenocarcinoma.
Complications: Mild bleeding, controlled with wedging. No pneumothorax on immediate cone-beam CT.
Disposition: Extubated and discharged from PACU after uneventful recovery.
primary_indication: Biopsy of solitary LUL pulmonary nodule
radiographic_findings: 20 mm irregular LUL apicoposterior segment nodule; no adenopathy
ebus_rose_result: Malignant epithelial cells consistent with adenocarcinoma on cryobiopsy
nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS pattern within lesion
bronch_indication: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy for LUL nodule
bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, immunohistochemistry, molecular profiling, PD-L1
final_diagnosis_prelim: Non-small cell lung carcinoma, favor adenocarcinoma on ROSE
follow_up_plan: Lung cancer clinic visit in 1 week for staging and treatment planning

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy (superDimension) with radial EBUS and transbronchial biopsies of left lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Daniel Rivera, 65-year-old male with 14 mm LLL peripheral nodule with faint PET uptake.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Highlights:
- EMN plan created from thin-cut CT; registration error 4.6 mm via anatomical landmarks.
- Radial EBUS showed eccentric view.
- Fluoroscopy confirmed position at lesion; no cone-beam CT available.
- Five forceps biopsies, two brushings and one mini-BAL obtained.
ROSE: Nondiagnostic, bronchial cells only.
Complications: None. No pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home with plan for repeat evaluation vs CT-guided biopsy.
primary_indication: Biopsy of small indeterminate LLL pulmonary nodule
radiographic_findings: 14 mm LLL lateral basal nodule with faint PET uptake; no adenopathy
lesion_location: Left lower lobe lateral basal segment
anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, topical and nebulized lidocaine
nav_sampling_tools: Transbronchial forceps, cytology brush, mini-BAL catheter
bronch_indication: ENB-guided biopsy of LLL nodule
bronch_tbbx_tool: Standard transbronchial forceps via extended working channel
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology and cytology
final_diagnosis_prelim: Nondiagnostic bronchoscopic biopsy; additional tissue sampling likely needed
disposition: Discharged home; plan discussed for CT-guided biopsy vs surveillance
follow_up_plan: Lung nodule clinic in 2 weeks to review options

note_text:
Central Airway Therapeutic Bronchoscopy Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis
3. Silicone stent placement
Patient: Patrick Hughes, 58-year-old male with prior prolonged intubation now with fixed upper airway obstruction and exertional stridor.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope size 11 and jet ventilation.
Findings: Short-segment concentric fibrotic stenosis 2 cm below vocal cords; ~70% luminal narrowing.
Intervention: Serial balloon dilations performed to 12 mm, then a 12 x 40 mm silicone straight stent placed across the stenotic segment. Postprocedure lumen patency ~10% residual narrowing.
Complications: Minor mucosal bleeding controlled with epinephrine.
Disposition: Extubated to PACU on 4 L nasal cannula and admitted overnight for airway monitoring.
primary_indication: Symptomatic postintubation tracheal stenosis
radiographic_findings: CT neck/chest showing 1.5 cm segment of subglottic tracheal narrowing ~6 mm diameter
prior_therapy: Brief trial of inhaled steroids and dilation at outside hospital
nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy for balloon sizing and stent position
bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for tracheal stenosis
bronch_guidance: Rigid bronchoscopy with fluoroscopy for stent positioning
final_diagnosis_prelim: Benign postintubation tracheal stenosis treated with balloon dilation and silicone stent
follow_up_plan: Clinic bronchoscopy in 4–6 weeks to reassess stent position and lumen

note_text:
Rigid Bronchoscopy Procedure Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy and mechanical debulking
2. Balloon dilation of left mainstem bronchus
Patient: Brenda Lewis, 73-year-old female with benign left mainstem bronchial stenosis after lung transplant.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid size 12 bronchoscope, jet ventilation.
Findings: Fibrotic annular stenosis at anastomotic site in left mainstem with ~60% narrowing and retained secretions distally.
Interventions: Mechanical dilation with rigid barrel and forceps followed by controlled balloon dilation to 10 mm. No stent placed.
Complications: Small mucosal tear without active bleeding. EBL ~20 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in OR, transferred to PACU then transplant ward.
primary_indication: Benign anastomotic stenosis after lung transplant
radiographic_findings: CT chest showing focal narrowing of left mainstem bronchus at anastomosis with distal air trapping
prior_therapy: Bronchoscopic balloon dilation x1 approximately 6 months prior
bronch_indication: Therapeutic bronchoscopic dilation of transplant anastomosis
bronch_immediate_complications: Small mucosal tear without ongoing bleeding
final_diagnosis_prelim: Benign post-transplant anastomotic stenosis with improved lumen post dilation
disposition: Transferred to transplant ward for overnight observation
follow_up_plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 3 months or sooner if symptoms recur

note_text:
Central Airway Stenting Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking
2. Y-shaped silicone stent placement
Patient: Raymond Scott, 69-year-old male with squamous cell carcinoma of the carina causing severe central airway obstruction.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope and intermittent jet ventilation.
Findings: Bulky endobronchial tumor involving distal trachea and extending into both mainstem bronchi causing ~80% obstruction.
Interventions: Mechanical debulking with rigid barrel and forceps followed by argon plasma coagulation. A custom 14 x 60/40 mm silicone Y stent was deployed with the main limb in distal trachea and branches in right and left main bronchi.
Complications: Brief desaturation during stent deployment, resolved with recruitment.
Disposition: Remained intubated postprocedure and transferred to ICU.
primary_indication: Malignant central airway obstruction involving carina
radiographic_findings: CT chest with carinal mass and near-occlusion of both mainstem bronchi
prior_therapy: Palliative radiation to mediastinum 1 year ago
nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy to confirm Y stent configuration
cao_primary_modality: Mechanical debulking, APC, and Y stent placement
stent_location: Distal trachea and both mainstem bronchi
bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction
bronch_guidance: Rigid bronchoscopy with fluoroscopic confirmation of stent
bronch_specimen_tests: Debulked tumor tissue sent for histology only
final_diagnosis_prelim: Known squamous cell carcinoma with central airway obstruction; palliative airway stenting performed
disposition: Remained intubated and transferred to ICU
follow_up_plan: ICU monitoring and oncology follow-up for palliative systemic therapy

note_text:
Bronchoscopic Lung Volume Reduction Note
Procedure: Zephyr endobronchial valve placement in right upper lobe
Patient: Maria Lopez, 64-year-old female with severe heterogeneous emphysema and hyperinflation.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.5 ETT; volume control ventilation.
Target lobe selection: Right upper lobe based on CT fissure analysis, perfusion scan, and quantitative CT. Chartis catheter evaluation demonstrated absence of collateral ventilation in RUL.
Intervention: Four Zephyr valves placed to occlude RUL segments (RB1, RB2, RB3, RB4+5 combined). Complete occlusion confirmed bronchoscopically.
Complications: Small right pneumothorax on immediate postprocedure CXR requiring 14 Fr pigtail chest tube.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit for monitoring with chest tube to water seal.
primary_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for severe RUL-predominant emphysema
radiographic_findings: Severe heterogeneous emphysema with RUL predominance; intact fissures on CT
prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy and pulmonary rehab
blvr_cv_assessment_method: CT fissure analysis, perfusion scanning, Chartis
pleural_procedure_type: Chest tube placement for BLVR pneumothorax
bronch_indication: BLVR in RUL for emphysema
bronch_immediate_complications: None during bronchoscopy; postprocedure pneumothorax treated with chest tube
pneumothorax_intervention: 14 Fr pigtail chest tube to water seal
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe emphysema treated with BLVR to RUL; postprocedure pneumothorax
disposition: Admitted to monitored bed with chest tube in place
follow_up_plan: Daily CXR until pneumothorax resolved; outpatient follow-up with PFTs at 4–6 weeks

note_text:
Bronchoscopic Lung Volume Reduction Note
Procedure: Attempted Zephyr valve placement in left upper lobe aborted due to collateral ventilation
Patient: Steven Brooks, 70-year-old male with severe emphysema.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT.
Summary:
- Target lobe: Left upper lobe based on CT heterogeneity and fissure completeness.
- Chartis assessment revealed persistent airflow consistent with significant collateral ventilation; BLVR not performed.
- No valves deployed. Airways irrigated and inspected.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Extubated in procedure room and discharged home after observation.
primary_indication: Evaluation for BLVR in LUL-predominant emphysema
radiographic_findings: CT with upper-lobe predominant emphysema, partially incomplete LUL fissures
prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler regimen and pulmonary rehab
blvr_cv_assessment_method: Chartis catheter and CT fissure analysis
blvr_chartis_result: Significant collateral ventilation; BLVR not performed
bronch_indication: BLVR evaluation with Chartis
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe emphysema with collateral ventilation; not a BLVR candidate
follow_up_plan: Pulmonary clinic for alternative advanced COPD therapies

note_text:
Whole Lung Lavage Procedure Note
Procedure: Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
Patient: Jason Phillips, 39-year-old male with autoimmune PAP, status post left lung lavage 3 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 39 Fr left-sided double-lumen tube, single-lung ventilation of left lung.
Lavage details: Right lung lavaged with warmed saline aliquots of 800–1000 mL. Total instilled volume 32 L; total effluent 27 L of progressively clearing milky fluid.
Complications: Brief episode of hypotension treated with vasopressor bolus; oxygenation adequate throughout.
Disposition: Remained intubated postprocedure and transferred to ICU on mechanical ventilation.
primary_indication: Therapeutic whole lung lavage for PAP
radiographic_findings: Ground-glass opacities and crazy-paving; improved on left after prior lavage
prior_therapy: Left lung lavage 3 weeks ago and GM-CSF therapy
anesthesia_agents: Propofol, fentanyl, rocuronium, sevoflurane, vasopressor support
bronch_indication: Airway management and lavage for PAP
bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy used intermittently to confirm DLT position and clear plugs
final_diagnosis_prelim: Autoimmune PAP after bilateral whole lung lavage
disposition: Remained intubated and transferred to ICU
follow_up_plan: Wean to extubation as tolerated; follow-up CT and PFT in 6–8 weeks

note_text:
Whole Lung Lavage Note (Abbreviated)
Procedure: Partial left lung lavage for PAP
Patient: Lauren Young, 46-year-old female with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and poor cardiopulmonary reserve.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with right-sided DLT. Plans for staged smaller-volume lavages.
Course: Left lung lavaged with 10 L of warm saline in 500–800 mL aliquots. Procedure terminated early due to rising airway pressures and modest hypoxia; total return 8.4 L.
Complications: Hypoxemia to 82%, responsive to recruitment and switch to two-lung ventilation.
Disposition: Extubated in OR to high-flow nasal cannula and admitted to ICU.
primary_indication: Therapeutic lavage for PAP with staged approach
radiographic_findings: Diffuse crazy-paving with moderate hypoxemia on room air
bronch_indication: Airway inspection and lavage management
bronch_guidance: Bronchoscopy used intermittently to reposition DLT and aspirate mucus
bronch_immediate_complications: Transient hypoxemia corrected with two-lung ventilation
final_diagnosis_prelim: Partial left lung lavage for PAP; staged approach planned
disposition: Admitted to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula
follow_up_plan: Consider repeat smaller-volume lavage once stable

note_text:
Foreign Body Bronchoscopy Note
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with removal of chicken bone from left lower lobe bronchus
Patient: Michael James, 45-year-old male with acute onset cough after eating chicken wings, CT showing airway foreign body.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid adult bronchoscope and jet ventilation.
Findings: Sharp bone fragment lodged in superior segment bronchus of LLL with surrounding granulation tissue.
Intervention: Bone removed piecemeal using rigid forceps and basket; granulation cauterized with APC. Airways suctioned clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to 86%, resolved with bag ventilation.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and observed for 4 hours on the ward.
primary_indication: Suspected food aspiration with focal obstruction
radiographic_findings: CT chest with hyperdense foreign body in LLL superior segment, distal atelectasis
lesion_location: Left lower lobe superior segment bronchus
bronch_indication: Foreign body removal
final_diagnosis_prelim: Food aspiration with complete foreign body removal
disposition: Observed on ward and discharged later the same day
follow_up_plan: Outpatient pulmonology follow-up if symptoms recur

note_text:
Pediatric Bronchoscopy Note
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with removal of pen cap from right mainstem bronchus
Patient: Ava Thompson, 6-year-old female who aspirated pen cap while playing at school.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with pediatric rigid bronchoscope.
Findings: Hollow plastic pen cap lodged in proximal right mainstem causing near-complete obstruction of RUL and RML.
Intervention: Foreign body grasped and removed intact with optical forceps. Airways suctioned and inspected to subsegmental level.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and observed in pediatric recovery; discharged home later that day.
primary_indication: Foreign body aspiration causing right-sided wheeze
radiographic_findings: Hyperinflated right lung with air-trapping on expiratory CXR
bronch_indication: Foreign body removal
final_diagnosis_prelim: Foreign body aspiration with complete removal
follow_up_plan: Routine pediatric follow-up with PCP

note_text:
Bronchial Thermoplasty Procedure Note
Session: 2 (left lower lobe) for severe asthma
Patient: Sarah Mitchell, 42-year-old female with severe persistent asthma uncontrolled on biologic therapy.
Sedation: Deep sedation with propofol infusion, native airway with bite block.
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscope advanced to segmental and subsegmental bronchi in left lower lobe. Bronchial thermoplasty catheter deployed and RF energy delivered per protocol. Total activations delivered: 50.
Complications: Mild transient bronchospasm treated with nebulized albuterol; no intubation required.
Disposition: Observed in bronchoscopy recovery for 6 hours and discharged home on prednisone taper.
primary_indication: Bronchial thermoplasty for severe asthma
radiographic_findings: Normal parenchyma; air trapping on expiratory CT
bronch_indication: BT session for severe asthma
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe asthma treated with BT LLL session
follow_up_plan: Return for third BT session in 3 weeks

note_text:
Bronchial Thermoplasty Procedure Note (Aborted)
Session: 1 (right lower lobe)
Patient: David Nguyen, 50-year-old male with severe steroid-dependent asthma.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Course: After initial BT activations in RLL basal segments (12 activations delivered), patient developed severe bronchospasm and hypoxia despite bronchodilator therapy. Procedure aborted and no further activations performed.
Complications: Acute asthma exacerbation requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation in ICU.
Disposition: Intubated, transferred to ICU for management.
primary_indication: Bronchial thermoplasty for severe asthma
radiographic_findings: No focal infiltrates; hyperinflation and airway wall thickening
ventilation_mode: Spontaneous ventilation; converted to mechanical ventilation after intubation
bronch_indication: Attempted BT session for severe asthma
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe asthma exacerbation during BT; procedure aborted
follow_up_plan: ICU management of asthma; reconsider BT once stable

note_text:
Medical Thoracoscopy Procedure Note
Procedure: Diagnostic medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies (no pleurodesis)
Patient: Patricia Foster, 62-year-old female with unilateral right exudative pleural effusion, concern for tuberculous pleuritis vs malignancy.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl plus local anesthesia.
Technique: Under ultrasound guidance, right 7th intercostal space selected. Approximately 1200 mL of straw-colored fluid drained. Semi-rigid thoracoscope introduced, revealing diffuse fibrinous exudate and scattered small nodules.
Multiple parietal pleural biopsies obtained; no talc instilled.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Chest tube left to water seal; admitted to ward.
primary_indication: Unexplained unilateral exudative pleural effusion
radiographic_findings: Moderate right pleural effusion with basal atelectasis
prior_therapy: Two prior diagnostic thoracenteses, cytology negative
anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, local lidocaine and bupivacaine
pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Fibrinous exudate and small parietal nodules, no obvious bulky tumor
bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, AFB smear/culture, fungal stains
final_diagnosis_prelim: Exudative pleural effusion; final pleural biopsy pending to rule out TB vs malignancy
disposition: Admitted with chest tube to water seal
follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs and tube management; outpatient follow-up after pathology

note_text:
Therapeutic Thoracentesis Note
Procedure: Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis complicated by small pneumothorax
Patient: William Carter, 79-year-old male with recurrent left pleural effusion and heart failure.
Sedation: Local anesthesia only.
Details: Using real-time ultrasound, left 8th intercostal space in posterior axillary line chosen. 1100 mL of clear straw-colored fluid removed via catheter. Patient developed mild pleuritic pain and cough at end of drainage; postprocedure ultrasound and CXR showed small apical pneumothorax.
No chest tube placed; patient observed with supplemental oxygen.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for monitoring.
primary_indication: Symptomatic recurrent left pleural effusion due to CHF
radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis
bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural fluid sent for chemistry and cytology
pneumothorax_intervention: Observation with supplemental oxygen; no chest tube
final_diagnosis_prelim: Transudative effusion due to CHF, small procedure-related pneumothorax
disposition: Admitted overnight for monitoring of pneumothorax
follow_up_plan: Repeat CXR in morning; adjust diuretics for volume management

note_text:
Diagnostic Bronchoscopy Note
Procedures:
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL
2. Transbronchial biopsies (forceps) for suspected sarcoidosis
Patient: Charlene King, 48-year-old female with bilateral hilar adenopathy and pulmonary nodules.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Findings: Cobblestoning and mild nodularity at segmental bronchi; otherwise normal airways.
Sampling: BAL in right middle lobe; six fluoroscopy-guided transbronchial biopsies from right lower lobe medial basal segment.
Complications: No significant bleeding; postprocedure CXR negative for pneumothorax.
Disposition: Discharged home after observation.
primary_indication: Diagnostic bronchoscopy for suspected sarcoidosis
radiographic_findings: Bilateral hilar adenopathy and perilymphatic nodules
prior_therapy: Short course of steroids with incomplete evaluation
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopy with BAL and TBBx for ILD/sarcoidosis
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, special stains, BAL for CD4/CD8 and cultures
final_diagnosis_prelim: Noncaseating granulomas on preliminary pathology; final stains pending
follow_up_plan: Clinic visit in 2 weeks to discuss pathology and treatment

note_text:
ICU Bedside Bronchoscopy Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL and mucus plug removal
Patient: Anthony Rogers, 68-year-old male intubated in ICU with lobar collapse and hypoxemic respiratory failure.
Setting: MICU bedside on mechanical ventilation.
Findings: Thick mucus plugs obstructing right lower lobe basal bronchi with complete lobar collapse on prior CXR.
Intervention: Aggressive saline lavage, suctioning, and BAL performed in RLL. Plugs removed and airways cleared.
Complications: Transient desaturation to 84% during lavage, resolved with recruitment.
Disposition: Remained intubated in ICU.
primary_indication: Diagnostic and therapeutic bronchoscopy for lobar collapse in ventilated patient
radiographic_findings: Complete right lower lobe collapse with mucus plugging on CT
anesthesia_agents: Propofol infusion, fentanyl drip, neuromuscular blockade held during procedure
bronch_indication: ICU bedside bronchoscopy for mucus plugging
bronch_specimen_tests: BAL sent for cell count and cultures
final_diagnosis_prelim: Atelectasis due to mucus plugging; plugs removed
disposition: Remained intubated in ICU on ventilator
follow_up_plan: Repeat CXR to document re-expansion; continue airway clearance strategies

note_text:
Transbronchial Cryobiopsy Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic cryobiopsy for fibrotic ILD
Patient: Jennifer Adams, 56-year-old female with progressive fibrotic interstitial lung disease of unclear etiology.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.5 ETT.
Details: Bronchoscope advanced to left lower lobe basal segments. Radial EBUS used to identify parenchymal sites distant from large vessels. Three cryobiopsies obtained using 1.9 mm cryoprobe and one standard forceps biopsy. Bronchial blocker placed prophylactically.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with blocker inflation and iced saline; no pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to monitored bed.
primary_indication: Cryobiopsy for diagnosis of fibrotic ILD
radiographic_findings: Peripheral reticulation and traction bronchiectasis in lower lobes
bronch_indication: Transbronchial cryobiopsy for ILD
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, special stains for HP vs UIP pattern
bronch_immediate_complications: Mild bleeding controlled with bronchial blocker
final_diagnosis_prelim: Adequate cryobiopsy specimens obtained; ILD pattern pending
follow_up_plan: ILD clinic visit after pathology and multidisciplinary review

note_text:
Robotic Bronchoscopic Radiofrequency Ablation Note
Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with RF ablation of RLL metastasis
Patient: Kevin White, 63-year-old male with oligometastatic colorectal cancer and 10 mm RLL nodule.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT.
Navigation: Ion robotic system used to access RLL lateral basal segment. CT-to-body registration error 2.0 mm. Radial EBUS confirmed solid lesion, cone-beam CT verified tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: RF ablation catheter advanced; ablation performed at 40 W for 480 seconds, peak temperature 85°C. Postablation CBCT showed ablation zone with ~5 mm margin.
Complications: Small perilesional hemorrhage, hemodynamically stable.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to telemetry.
primary_indication: Local treatment of single lung metastasis
radiographic_findings: 10 mm RLL lateral basal pulmonary nodule
lesion_location: Right lower lobe lateral basal segment
nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view of lesion
nav_imaging_verification: Cone-beam CT before and after ablation
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic RF ablation of RLL metastasis
bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
final_diagnosis_prelim: Oligometastatic colorectal metastasis treated with bronchoscopic RF ablation
follow_up_plan: CT chest in 3 months to assess ablation zone

note_text:
Bronchoscopic Microwave Ablation Note
Procedure: EMN-guided microwave ablation of left upper lobe peripheral nodule
Patient: Teresa Murphy, 60-year-old female with small presumed primary NSCLC not surgical candidate.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.5 ETT.
Navigation: superDimension EMN platform used to access 14 mm LUL anterior segment nodule. Radial EBUS showed eccentric view; cone-beam CT confirmed antenna in lesion.
Ablation: Emprint microwave antenna delivered via extended working channel, 65 W for 360 seconds, peak temperature 100°C. Postablation CBCT demonstrated appropriate ablation zone.
Complications: Mild hemoptysis (~20 mL) and small left apical pneumothorax requiring 10 Fr pigtail catheter.
Disposition: Admitted to monitored bed.

note_text:
Bronchoscopic Cryoablation Note
Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with cryoablation of subpleural RUL lesion
Patient: Brian Edwards, 71-year-old male with small peripheral NSCLC and severe COPD.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT.
Navigation: Monarch robotic system used to reach 12 mm RUL apical segment lesion. Radial EBUS confirmed lesion; CBCT demonstrated tip within lesion.
Ablation: 2.4 mm cryoprobe advanced through working channel; two freeze–thaw cycles of 360 seconds each performed. Ice ball seen on CBCT encompassing lesion with ~4–5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild transient hemoptysis; no pneumothorax on immediate imaging.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA
Patient: James Carter, 64-year-old male with a right upper lobe mass and PET-avid mediastinal adenopathy.
Indication: Mediastinal staging prior to possible surgical resection.
Setting: Bronchoscopy suite at Naval Medical Center Atlantic. General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 mm), volume control ventilation.
Bronchoscopic findings: Normal vocal cords and central airways without endobronchial tumor. No endobronchial obstruction.
EBUS procedure: Olympus BF-UC180F scope introduced via ETT. Systematic survey performed. Enlarged nodes visualized at stations 4R, 7, and 11R. Three passes obtained from each station using a 21G Olympus Vizishot needle. ROSE showed malignant cells at 4R concerning for non-small cell lung cancer; stations 7 and 11R showed benign lymphocytes.
Elastography used, demonstrating heterogeneous (blue-predominant) pattern at 4R and homogeneous green pattern at 7 and 11R. No intranodal forceps biopsies were performed.
Complications: Minimal bleeding at puncture sites controlled with suction; estimated blood loss 5 mL. No hypoxia, pneumothorax, or hemodynamic instability.
Disposition: Patient extubated in the procedure room, observed in PACU, then discharged home the same day with routine postbronchoscopy instructions. Plan for follow-up visit in 1 week to review final pathology and complete staging.

bronch_specimen_tests: Cytology, cell block, flow cytometry

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA under monitored anesthesia care
Patient: Maria Hernandez, 58-year-old female with biopsy-proven left upper lobe adenocarcinoma and PET-avid mediastinal lymphadenopathy.
Indication: Mediastinal and hilar staging prior to definitive therapy.
Setting: Naval Medical Center Atlantic bronchoscopy suite. Monitored anesthesia care using propofol infusion and fentanyl. Laryngeal mask airway (size 4) with spontaneous ventilation on supplemental oxygen.
Bronchoscopy: Normal upper airway. No visible endobronchial tumor. Mild extrinsic impression at the left mainstem bronchus.
EBUS: Fujifilm EB-530US scope used. Systematic survey completed. Lymph nodes at stations 4L, 7, and 11L identified. A 22G needle was used for TBNA. Four passes were obtained from 7 and 11L, three from 4L. ROSE available and demonstrated abundant lymphocytes in all samples without definite malignant cells.
Elastography not used due to operator preference. No intranodal forceps biopsies performed.
Complications: None. Hemodynamics stable. Estimated blood loss <5 mL.
Disposition: Patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged home after 2 hours of observation with standard postprocedure instructions.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures performed: (1) Flexible bronchoscopy with airway inspection, (2) Linear EBUS-TBNA of mediastinal and hilar nodes.
Patient: Robert Lee, 71-year-old male with suspected recurrent small cell lung cancer and new mediastinal adenopathy after chemoradiation.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia, endotracheal tube 8.5 mm, pressure control ventilation.
Bronchoscopic findings: Mild radiation-related mucosal changes. No discrete endobronchial mass. Carina sharp.
EBUS: Olympus BF-UC180F scope. Systematic nodal evaluation. Stations 2R, 4R, 7, and 10R identified. Nodes at 4R and 7 were enlarged. A 21G Vizishot needle was used. Three passes per station at 4R and 7, two passes at 2R and 10R. ROSE showed malignant cells at 7 consistent with small cell carcinoma; other stations with lymphocytes.
Elastography not available on this system. No intranodal forceps biopsies performed.
Complications: None. EBL 10 mL.
Plan: Await final cytology. Given evidence of nodal recurrence, patient will be referred to medical oncology.
Disposition: Extubated in OR, transported to PACU in stable condition and later admitted to oncology ward.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Robotic-assisted navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS and transbronchial biopsies of a right lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Patricia Nguyen, 67-year-old female, former smoker, with 18 mm RLL peripheral pulmonary nodule and positive PET.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
Navigation: Ion robotic bronchoscopy platform used. CT-to-body surface registration successful with registration error ~3 mm. Planned pathway to superior segment RLL nodule generated.
Radial EBUS: Concentric solid lesion pattern obtained at target.
Sampling: Tool-in-lesion confirmed by cone-beam CT. Six transbronchial forceps biopsies, two brushings, and one 21G needle aspiration performed. No cryobiopsy.
Complications: Mild self-limited bleeding controlled with wedging and cold saline. No pneumothorax on immediate fluoroscopy.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in procedure room and discharged from PACU after uneventful recovery.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS and fluoroscopic guidance for biopsy of a left upper lobe nodule.
Patient: David Brown, 59-year-old male, active smoker, with 22 mm PET-avid LUL nodule.
Sedation: Moderate sedation using midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block and spontaneous ventilation.
Navigation: SuperDimension electromagnetic platform used. CT-based planning and registration via anatomical landmarks. Registration error approximately 4 mm.
Radial EBUS: Eccentric view of solid lesion obtained.
Sampling: Tool position confirmed by fluoroscopy only. Five forceps biopsies and two brushings performed. No cryobiopsy. ROSE with atypical cells suspicious for malignancy.
Complications: Minor bleeding controlled with iced saline and epinephrine; no desaturation. No pneumothorax on fluoroscopic screening.
Sedation reversal: Naloxone administered at end of case for slow emergence.
Disposition: Observed for 2 hours and discharged home with instructions for urgent return if hemoptysis or dyspnea.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Monarch robotic-assisted navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsies of a right middle lobe nodule.
Patient: Angela White, 63-year-old female with 14 mm PET-avid RML nodule in a never-smoker.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via 8.0 mm ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Navigation: Monarch platform with CT-based virtual bronchoscopy. Registration completed with 2.5 mm error. Radial EBUS with concentric view at target.
Sampling: Tool-in-lesion confirmed by cone-beam CT. Four cryobiopsies using 1.1 mm cryoprobe and four standard forceps biopsies were obtained. ROSE suggested possible metastatic adenocarcinoma.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with occlusion and iced saline. Small right apical pneumothorax noted on immediate postprocedure CXR requiring pigtail chest tube placement.
Disposition: Patient observed overnight on telemetry with chest tube to water seal.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: (1) Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, (2) Argon plasma coagulation, (3) Silicone stent placement.
Patient: Michael Green, 72-year-old male with severe dyspnea from distal tracheal tumor causing critical central airway obstruction.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia, rigid bronchoscope size 12 with coaxial 7.0 ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Findings: Exophytic tumor arising from distal trachea extending to main carina with approximately 90 percent luminal obstruction.
Interventions: Mechanical coring of tumor using rigid barrel and forceps, followed by argon plasma coagulation of residual tumor. Final obstruction estimated at less than 10 percent. A 14 x 50 mm silicone straight stent was placed across the distal trachea and main carina under bronchoscopic guidance.
Complications: Transient hypotension during induction treated with vasopressor bolus; no airway complications. EBL 50 mL.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated and was transferred to ICU for overnight observation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking and placement of covered metallic stent in left mainstem bronchus.
Patient: Linda Davis, 69-year-old female with left mainstem obstruction from endobronchial adenocarcinoma causing collapse of left lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via rigid bronchoscope size 11 with jet ventilation.
Findings: Friable tumor completely occluding left mainstem bronchus at its origin.
Intervention: Mechanical debulking using rigid barrel, suction, and forceps until lumen opened. Argon plasma coagulation applied to tumor base. Residual obstruction approximately 20 percent. A 12 x 40 mm covered self-expanding metallic stent was deployed under bronchoscopic and fluoroscopic guidance into the left mainstem.
Complications: None. EBL 30 mL.
Disposition: Extubated and transferred to PACU on 2 L nasal cannula. Postprocedure CXR showed re-expansion of left lung.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and mechanical debulking for endobronchial tumor.
Patient: Samuel Ortiz, 55-year-old male with endobronchial tumor in right mainstem causing moderate obstruction.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block.
Findings: Polypoid tumor arising from right mainstem bronchus causing approximately 70 percent obstruction.
Intervention: Multiple cycles of cryotherapy applied using flexible cryoprobe followed by mechanical debulking with forceps and suction. Residual obstruction estimated at 20 percent. No stent placed.
Complications: Mild oozing controlled with cold saline and epinephrine instillation. No hypoxia.
Disposition: Recovered in bronchoscopy unit and discharged home the same day with close oncology follow-up.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr endobronchial valves to left upper lobe.
Patient: Karen Young, 68-year-old female with severe emphysema and hyperinflation despite maximal medical therapy.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
Target selection: Left upper lobe selected based on CT fissure analysis and perfusion imaging showing heterogeneous emphysema.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis performed in LUL segments with absence of collateral ventilation.
Intervention: Three Zephyr valves placed in LUL segments (LB1+2, LB3). Post-deployment airway inspection confirmed good seal.
Complications: None. Minimal secretions cleared. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation, early ambulation, and serial chest radiographs.

radiographic_findings: CT with heterogeneous emphysema, most severe in LUL; intact fissures; hyperinflation on lung volumes
prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation

bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for emphysema
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe heterogeneous emphysema treated with BLVR valves
follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs for 2 days and clinic follow-up in 4 weeks with PFTs

note_text:

Target selection: Right upper lobe based on CT fissure analysis; Chartis not performed.
Intervention: Two Spiration valves placed in RUL segments (RB1 and RB2+3). There was good collapse of RUL airways on bronchoscopy.
Complications: None during procedure. No immediate pneumothorax on CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr valves to left lower lobe in heterogeneous emphysema.
Patient: Emily Rogers, 70-year-old female with severe dyspnea and LLL-predominant emphysema.
Sedation: General anesthesia with ETT.
Target selection: Left lower lobe based on CT and perfusion imaging. Chartis performed with low but persistent airflow suggesting borderline collateral ventilation; decision made to proceed with caution.
Intervention: Two Zephyr valves placed in LLL segments. Endoscopic assessment showed good valve seating.
Complications: Transient desaturation to 86 percent corrected with increased FiO2. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted to monitored bed for observation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Brian Scott, 42-year-old male with confirmed autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and progressive dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube for single-lung ventilation.
Procedure details: Left lung lavaged using warm saline aliquots of 750 to 1000 mL with manual chest percussion. Total instilled volume 30 L; total effluent 25 L of progressively clearer, initially milky return.
Complications: Transient hypotension treated with fluids and vasopressors; oxygenation maintained with right lung ventilation.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated at end of case and was transported to ICU for overnight ventilatory support and monitoring.

Complications: Brief desaturation to low 80s during large aliquot, improved with temporary pause and recruitment maneuvers.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula for monitoring.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung) aborted early due to hypoxemia.
Patient: Kevin Foster, 49-year-old male with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen ET tube.
Procedure details: Left lung lavage initiated with 1 L aliquots. After 6 L instilled and 4.8 L returned, patient developed refractory hypoxemia despite recruitment maneuvers and increased FiO2.
Decision: Lavage aborted, fluid drained as completely as possible, and both lungs ventilated.
Complications: Hypoxemia to 78 percent, improved after stopping lavage. No hemodynamic collapse.
Disposition: Patient left intubated and transported to ICU for continued respiratory support.

Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchial thermoplasty session 3 treating bilateral upper lobes.
Patient: Hannah Lewis, 39-year-old female with severe refractory asthma.
Sedation: General anesthesia with laryngeal mask airway.
Procedure details: BT catheter deployed sequentially in RUL and LUL segmental airways. Total of 60 activations delivered (30 per side).
Complications: Mild postprocedure cough and chest tightness; no severe bronchospasm.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation due to distance from hospital and prior asthma exacerbations.
primary_indication: Bronchial thermoplasty, final session
radiographic_findings: Hyperinflated lungs, no focal consolidation
prior_therapy: Two prior BT sessions to lower lobes
bronch_indication: Bronchial thermoplasty final session for severe asthma
final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe asthma treated with completion BT
follow_up_plan: Clinic visit in 6 to 8 weeks to evaluate BT response

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion.
Patient: George Turner, 76-year-old male with recurrent left pleural effusion and suspected malignancy.
Anesthesia: Monitored anesthesia care with local anesthesia and moderate sedation.
Procedure details: Under ultrasound guidance, left 6th intercostal space in midaxillary line selected. 1.5 L of straw-colored fluid drained. Semi-rigid thoracoscope introduced; diffuse parietal pleural nodularity and studding observed. Multiple parietal pleural biopsies taken. Talc slurry pleurodesis performed after complete drainage.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for pain control and chest tube management.
primary_indication: Recurrent unilateral pleural effusion suspicious for malignancy
radiographic_findings: Large recurrent left pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis
anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, local lidocaine and bupivacaine
pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural nodularity and studding suspicious for malignancy
bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology, cytology, flow cytometry
final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspected malignant pleural effusion; final pleural biopsy results pending
disposition: Admitted with chest tube to suction
follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs; remove chest tube once output low and lung fully expanded

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Ultrasound-guided therapeutic thoracentesis.
Patient: Isabel Morales, 73-year-old female with recurrent right pleural effusion due to heart failure.
Anesthesia: Local anesthesia with lidocaine and mild anxiolysis.
Procedure details: Right posterior 8th intercostal space chosen under ultrasound guidance. 900 mL of clear serous fluid removed via catheter system. Opening pressure not formally measured.
Complications: None; no cough or chest pain.
Disposition: Discharged home after brief observation.
primary_indication: Symptomatic recurrent right pleural effusion
radiographic_findings: Moderate right pleural effusion on CXR and ultrasound
bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural fluid for chemistry, cytology, microbiology
final_diagnosis_prelim: Transudative effusion likely due to heart failure
follow_up_plan: Outpatient management of heart failure and repeat thoracentesis as needed

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with tunneled pleural catheter placement and talc poudrage.
Patient: Ethan Hall, 65-year-old male with known metastatic lung cancer and recurrent right malignant pleural effusion.
Sedation: Monitored anesthesia care with moderate sedation and local anesthetic.
Procedure details: Under ultrasound guidance, right 7th intercostal space selected. 1.8 L of serosanguinous pleural fluid drained. Thoracoscopy revealed nodular parietal pleural implants. Talc poudrage pleurodesis performed and indwelling tunneled pleural catheter placed for outpatient drainage.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Admitted overnight; discharged next day with home health support for catheter care.
primary_indication: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion requiring definitive management
radiographic_findings: Moderate right pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis of lower lobe
pleural_procedure_type: Medical thoracoscopy with tunneled pleural catheter
pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Multiple parietal pleural nodules consistent with metastatic carcinoma
bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and molecular profiling
final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural disease in setting of metastatic lung cancer
disposition: Overnight admission, then discharge with tunneled catheter
follow_up_plan: Outpatient oncology and IP clinic follow-up for catheter management

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL and transbronchial biopsies for interstitial lung disease evaluation.
Patient: Natalie Reed, 53-year-old female with progressive dyspnea and bilateral ground-glass opacities.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with fentanyl and midazolam; native airway.
Bronchoscopic findings: Normal airways to subsegmental level.
Sampling: BAL performed in right middle lobe. Fluoroscopy-guided transbronchial biopsies (6 samples) obtained from right lower lobe lateral basal segment using standard forceps.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with iced saline; no pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home from recovery area.
primary_indication: Diagnostic bronchoscopy for ILD workup
radiographic_findings: Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities with lower lobe predominance
bronch_indication: Diagnostic bronchoscopy for ILD with BAL and TBBx
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, special stains, BAL for cell count and cultures
final_diagnosis_prelim: Pathology pending; BAL lymphocytic predominance
follow_up_plan: ILD clinic follow-up in 2 weeks to review pathology

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryobiopsies for interstitial lung disease.
Patient: Carlos Rivera, 47-year-old male with suspected fibrotic ILD.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation.
Procedure details: Bronchoscope advanced to RLL; fluoroscopy and radial EBUS used to identify safe parenchymal target areas. Three cryobiopsies obtained from RLL basal segments using 1.9 mm cryoprobe and one standard forceps biopsy. Bronchial blocker placed prophylactically.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with temporary bronchial blocker inflation and iced saline. No pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.
primary_indication: Cryobiopsy for ILD diagnosis
radiographic_findings: Reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis in bilateral lower lobes
nav_rebus_view: Lung parenchyma without vessels by radial EBUS
bronch_indication: Transbronchial cryobiopsy for ILD
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology including special stains for fibrosis and inflammation
bronch_immediate_complications: Mild bleeding controlled with bronchial blocker
final_diagnosis_prelim: Cryobiopsy specimens adequate; final ILD diagnosis pending
follow_up_plan: ILD multidisciplinary conference review after pathology available

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryobiopsy complicated by pneumothorax.
Patient: Megan Collins, 60-year-old female with suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Procedure details: Cryobiopsies obtained from left lower lobe basal segments using 1.9 mm cryoprobe (3 samples). Fluoroscopy used. After third biopsy, patient developed decreased breath sounds and rising airway pressures.
Complications: Left pneumothorax confirmed on fluoroscopy and ultrasound. A 14 Fr pigtail chest tube placed with immediate improvement.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit with chest tube to suction.
primary_indication: Cryobiopsy for suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis
radiographic_findings: Centrilobular nodules and mosaic attenuation
prior_therapy: Antigen avoidance and steroids with partial response
nav_rebus_view: Parenchymal target free of large vessels on radial EBUS
bronch_indication: Transbronchial cryobiopsy for ILD
bronch_specimen_tests: Histology for HP pattern
pneumothorax_intervention: 14 Fr pigtail chest tube to suction
final_diagnosis_prelim: Cryobiopsy adequate; final pathology pending
disposition: Admitted to step-down unit with chest tube
follow_up_plan: Daily CXR; remove chest tube once air leak resolved and lung expanded

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of peripheral left lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Zachary Price, 66-year-old male with oligometastatic colorectal cancer to lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Ion robotic platform used to access 12 mm LLL peripheral metastasis. Registration error 2.3 mm. Radial EBUS confirmed solid lesion; cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: RFA probe advanced through working channel. Ablation performed at 50 W for 600 seconds with maximum temperature 90 degrees Celsius. Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated satisfactory ablation zone with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild perilesional hemorrhage without hemodynamic compromise.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.
primary_indication: Local ablation of oligometastatic colorectal metastasis to lung
radiographic_findings: 12 mm LLL peripheral nodule consistent with metastasis
lesion_location: Left lower lobe lateral basal segment
nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view of lesion
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic RF ablation of LLL metastasis
bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
ablation_complication_immediate: Minor perilesional hemorrhage without hemodynamic compromise
final_diagnosis_prelim: Oligometastatic colorectal metastasis treated with bronchoscopic RFA
follow_up_plan: Repeat CT chest in 3 months to assess ablation zone

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic microwave ablation (MWA) of right upper lobe peripheral nodule.
Patient: Julia Bennett, 62-year-old female with solitary lung metastasis from renal cell carcinoma.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: superDimension EMN platform used to reach 18 mm RUL posterior segment nodule. Fluoroscopy and cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: Microwave antenna advanced through extended working channel. Ablation performed with Emprint MWA system at 60 W for 420 seconds. Postablation imaging demonstrated adequate ablation zone with 8 mm margin.
Complications: Transient hemoptysis of approximately 15 mL, resolved spontaneously.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to telemetry.
primary_indication: Local control of solitary lung metastasis
radiographic_findings: 18 mm RUL posterior segment peripheral nodule
nav_rebus_view: Eccentric radial EBUS view of lesion
nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy and cone-beam CT pre- and postablation
nav_sampling_tools: Microwave antenna through extended working channel
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic microwave ablation of RUL metastasis
bronch_guidance: EMN, radial EBUS, and cone-beam CT
final_diagnosis_prelim: Solitary RCC lung metastasis treated with bronchoscopic MWA
follow_up_plan: CT chest in 3 months to assess ablation response

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic cryoablation of peripheral right lower lobe lesion.
Patient: Ryan Cooper, 69-year-old male with small presumed primary NSCLC not amenable to surgery.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with ETT.
Navigation: Monarch robotic platform used to reach 16 mm RLL superior segment lesion. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion.
Ablation: Flexible cryoprobe advanced and three freeze-thaw cycles performed (each 300 seconds). Postablation cone-beam CT demonstrated ice ball encompassing lesion with 5 mm margin.
Complications: Mild transient hemoptysis and temporary increase in oxygen requirement; no pneumothorax.
Disposition: Admitted overnight to monitored bed.
primary_indication: Local ablation of early-stage NSCLC in nonoperative candidate
radiographic_findings: 16 mm RLL superior segment pulmonary nodule, PET-avid
bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic cryoablation of NSCLC
bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
bronch_immediate_complications: Mild transient hemoptysis and increased oxygen requirement
ablation_complication_immediate: Mild hemoptysis and transient hypoxia, both resolved
final_diagnosis_prelim: Early-stage NSCLC treated with bronchoscopic cryoablation
follow_up_plan: CT chest in 3 months to evaluate ablation zone; oncology follow-up
